@joshelser, with this pull request, I am trying to mimic what has been done on the Apache Fluo website.  The Fluo website has two kinds of Jekyll posts (blog and release). Blog posts are self-explanatory. Release posts contain the release notes for the release and links to resources (binary tarball, docs, javadocs, etc) for that release. Below are examples each post type:

https://fluo.apache.org/blog/2016/06/02/fluo-moving-to-apache/
https://fluo.apache.org/release/fluo-1.0.0-incubating/

When you go to https://fluo.apache.org/news/, you see all posts (blog & release).  This was done to avoid creating two posts (a release post and a blog post announcing the release).  When you go https://fluo.apache.org/release/, you only see releases (the pre-apache releases have been excluded).  Currently, the page https://fluo.apache.org/blog/ redirects to /news/ but it could show only blog posts.  This system has made releases easier to Fluo.  You just need to create one markdown document and the release will show up in 3 locations automatically ( 'latest news' on main page, the news archive '/news/', and release archive '/release/').
To be clear, this PR doesn't make releases Jekyll posts but I would like to do this in a later PR.

May want to point out https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/HDFS-3702 as an option starting with Hadoop 2.8, so that if the node goes down and can't be brought back up, you can still recover using the WAL.

> so that if the node goes down and can't be brought back up, you can still recover using the WAL.

I'm not sure I understand the reasoning behind that logic (admittedly, it's "early"). Specifically, how would a failure of the local node be any different than a failure of a non-local DN in the write pipeline? Also, aren't there performance implications when using hflush to avoid the local node (not even just the write side, but the read side would be unable to use SCR's when the local DN doesn't have those blocks).

> I'm not sure I understand the reasoning behind that logic (admittedly, it's "early"). Specifically, how would a failure of the local node be any different than a failure of a non-local DN in the write pipeline?

It might be how we create/use the WAL. It's possible that a tserver can create a WAL and open an output stream to the first block, but never actually write any data to it (see ACCUMULO-4004). I'm not quite sure of the state of the first block and file from an HDFS perspective if the node dies while in this state (WAL created, open input stream to the first block). But, I can say that this does cause a problem (in Accumulo 1.6.4 at least).

> It might be how we create/use the WAL. It's possible that a tserver can create a WAL and open an output stream to the first block, but never actually write any data to it (see ACCUMULO-4004). But, I can say that this does cause a problem (in Accumulo 1.6.4 at least).

Ok, thanks for the details, Dave. If we have a scenario that can reliably reproduce this, I can likely find an HDFS expert to give us some context on what is happened at the HDFS layer. I'm not sure how to inspect the state of that block nor would I know what would be "expected" or "correct" :)

Can you still create `#section` links when the manual is in the iframe?

We actually publish the manual to Maven Central. I'd almost rather serve the pages from there, and drop the additional hosting. Putting in the iframe may make it easier to do that, because we can make it look like we're still hosting it. If section links still work, it may be best to just wrap the manuals in their original locations, but link to the manual on Maven Central, rather than change the link in order to keep the unwrapped version at the previous location.
@ctubbsii, I like the idea of external hosting but the latest user manuals for 1.7 and 1.8 published on the website don't match the 1.8.0 and 1.7.2 releases published to maven central
I agree it makes sense to move the old ones so links go to the iframe version. Good point on the external hosting. We tend to update the manual between releases with typo and related fixes.

Overall, I'm not convinced that it's better to have the manuals embedded into the site. It adds complexity to the site layout, and maintenance. It also has some side-effects: Links directly to the manual (which includes all of the links inside the manuals themselves) will still go to the raw, unwrapped version. It also makes it harder for users to right-click (or Ctrl-S) to save a copy of the manual.

While those issues aren't insurmountable, and the windowed look does look nice enough so far as it goes, I think maybe it's better to just open the manual in a separate window/tab. That's a much simpler way to address the navigation issue, is a much smaller change, and requires far less maintenance. That way, the manuals will continue to be thought of as separate, standalone items, which are independently downloadable and portable regardless of the website.

After an exhaustive search through this code, the only reason I can come up with is an issue with a member reference in the underlying HeapIterator.  The scenario would be as follows:

thread 1: calls hasTop() which is invoked on then in memory data source
thread 2: calls switchSource which sets up the new datasource and calls seek which results in topIdx being set
thread1: calls next() which gets a value of null for topIdx

So if topIdx is marked as volatile then this should not happen.

One thing that was in the back of my mind is how to support "bounded summaries". For example, we would want to avoid storing 1M CVs if a user had that many in a table (for some reason). Could/should this be a primitive on summaries (how to limit them)? Or, would it be some implementation detail which we could provide some common-implementation logic?
@rweeks this is an attempt to generalize what we discussed at the accumulo summit.
Cool beans. Thanks, Mike! This feels like a really nice improvement.
I'm OK if you merge it in now. I'll work on the improvements on top of the changes I made here.

> For example, we would want to avoid storing 1M CVs if a user had that many in a table (for some reason).

I think we should address this issue in some way while considering the following.
- Fetching summaries should be relatively fast.  Gigantic summaries will stymie this goal.
- When a users summarizer does produce a gigantic summary, it would be nice if we helped them debug it.

I am thinking one way to accomplish these goals is to store gigantic summaries, but only read summaries under a certain size.  The size of a serialized summary could be written first.  When a summary is read this size will be the first bit of info.  If the summary is over a certain size an error could be logged and that file would be treated like it had no summary.  We could also add a enum that indicates gigantic summaries were present.  Since the summary is stored, it would give the user a chance to use rfile-info to look at whats in the summary for debugging.

We also need to stress in the javadoc that summaries are intended to be small.

@ctubbsii, I thought we could just put it out there. If things change, they'll probably be small but I will update the blog post.

In the ASF, there is a clear line drawn between released software and unreleased software, and promoting or marketing unreleased software in the ASF is a big no-no. Even beta or alpha versions must be voted on and released.

Development should happen in the developer forums (mailing list). The blogs on the website are not developer forums. It's intended for users.

I think it's fine to post-date the blog into the far future, so it doesn't get published by Jekyll, or make it into the RSS feed for blogs, and then update the date after release. Or, just hold the PR open until after the release. This is a good staging area, and it'd be good to have some blogs ready to go to market 2.0.0, after we approve a release.

For reference, [this page](https://www.apache.org/dev/release-distribution.html#unreleased) discusses/forbids distributing material or advertising which encourages the use of unreleased software outside the development community.

Aside from the last paragraph, I really don't think we have to wait to post this entry.

Presenting work that has been done in Accumulo is fine. It shows activity in the project and defeats the nay-sayer's that claim the project is dead. That can be done in a way that doesn't encourage users to not use official releases.
